comments.body: good idea, but what would we use the salt for?

@steeldoge i don't know... it could be a building block, but i can't think of anything else. I'm sure Mojang would be able to find a use for it. I did find this online which would tie salt in with copper: "Copper is one of the least resistant metals to salt-related corrosion. Over time, copper pipes will turn bluish-green with exposure and eventually crumble away. Galvanized steel and cast iron are more resistant to saltwater corrosion, but exposure over time can still cause damage." Maybe if you add salt and copper together it makes corroded copper (the teal coloring) instantly. Also, salt melts ice in real life. Maybe in minecraft too?

It could also be used to do the following; It could be used to stop snow accumulation, decrease the freezing point of water in order to prevent freezing creating salt water in the process, and it could even be sprinkled on dirt blocks to stop plant growth including grass until the block is either dug up and put back down (equivalent to turning over the dirt) or washed to flush out the salt. An excellent way to ruin farmland, clear out snow, and maintain a supply of liquid water in a cold place such that it can't be used for farming. For this addition to make sense the following would probably be needed; The conversion of oceans in Minecraft to saltwater after salt is added and the addition of some method of desalination such as distillation or freezing it and melting out the more saline portions.

I agree. I was about to post this same suggestion. I think that it would make a lot of sense. I think that Netherite, being as indestructible as it is, it shouldn't be destroyed when it runs out of durability.

I think this would be nice but it doesn't make sense, the elytra are these rare basically dragon (so they're almost organic wings that become disenchanted when the break

Netherite is a metal and like metal tools it makes sense that it breaks, has nothing organic about it, and you would repair with a netherite ingot so you might as well make new gear because it loses all enchantement anyways, and for anyone who actually get fortune 3 and knows how and were to get diamonds, chestplates are even easy to get, and to get levels you just fight the enderdragon once and you get like 70 levels for enchantments

These comments are unhinged. A tool not breaking is at best a quality-of-life issue, since either you aren't using Mending and you'd need another Netherite tool to repair it anyway, or you are using Mending and the only time this is an issue is when you are mining a lot and forget to swap a tool out when its at low durability. So, what is netherite; a rare material that just slightly upgrades diamond gear and is fire/lava proof. Its role is clearly to create late-game gear that is difficult for the player to accidentally lose, because the materials to make it are so rare. It is in the exact same category as an elytra. And that was deemed rare enough not to break when it runs out of durability. So, suggesting that netherite tools and armor should do the same is a completely fair argument.

And, if it's a lore reason, you can come up with a reason either way. Like, oooo, netherite is so incredibly tough it can only ever get worn down, not destroyed. That's why you find it in a scrap after all this time!

Given that recent updates have been so Nether focused, it really would make sense to add netherrack stairs, slabs, and walls to make it more consistent with other stone related blocks such as cobblestone, granite, andestite, diorite, etc.

Netherrack is the most common block in the Nether by far and yet the only blocks it has to represent it are... itself and two ore blocks. It feels like a small disservice to it that it doesn't have some block variations by now.
